instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message:
No sign of liquid. 

came in with 5.10 V on PPDCIN

Had a 1.ohm short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>. Found shorts on <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> and <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>. Replaced them and now have 2.588kohm on <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>. 

Replaced ISL and had <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>, but now its gone and I dont have anything on PPDCIN anymore either. 


PPDCIN - 28.51 kohm.

The only original charger I have is an 87 W USB C, so I have been using a couple adapters from 60 w Magsafe 2. 


Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message: Use the 87 watt....sounds like bad ISL

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> has firmware.
Did you solder new chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message:
Ok great, on the 87.

Yes I soldered <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> from donor...

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message:
So you don't get anything from charger now?
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> is 0V, as PPDCIN too?
Change <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> again; maybe <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message: Ok. Start with <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>, then move on to <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message:
You may try to reflow them first.
Be sure to get good solders...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message:
Is there stencils available to reball these chips that you know of? <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>, <CHIP>U4650</CHIP>, ISL?

These chips came off of donor and I would feel more confident in their functionality if I could reball them

You mentioned that <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> has firmware. Does that mean that I cannot buy individually, that is has to come off of a donor? 

Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message:
These small chips don't need reball usually.
Just be sure no big difference between pads and solder directly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> and <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>, still 0 voltage on F4700. 

 <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> - .005V / 8.05K Resistance. (seems high)

Feeling Lost, LOL.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5.10V on PPDCIN
threads.message: Check continuity for the flex between MLB and USB-C port.
